docs.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Monique Brown, a writer and editor from Brooklyn, visited a physician, worried about her heavy periods and bleeding between menstruation. Her disorder was diagnosed as fibroids, she said, noncancerous tumors that can grow in the uterus. ''It's normal,'' she recalled being told. ''Everybody has them.''

headline.main: Women Seek Choices When Fibroid Tumors Strike

docs.abstract: Article on noncancerous uterine fibroid tumors and alternatives to hysterectomies that women of childbearing age are beginning to demand; Sens Jean Carnahan, James Jeffords and Barbara Mikulski have introduced legislation calling for allocating $10 million a year for four years toward research on fibroids through National Institutes of Health as well as educational campaign; photo; diagram (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A couple whose son was stillborn two years ago is suing Yale-New Haven Hospital, claiming it lost or misplaced the body. The couple, Kimberly Zilinskas, 25, and Leonard Liscio, 31, say that the hospital has never accounted for the loss and that they are suing to try to find out what happened to their son's body. The suit, filed recently in State Superior Court in Meriden, maintains that the hospital showed ''gross negligence and failure of accountability'' in the August 2000 delivery.

headline.main: Lawsuit Claims Hospital Lost Body of Stillborn Son

docs.abstract: Kimberly Zilinskas and Leonard Liscio, whose son was stillborn at Yale-New Haven Hospital in August 2000, charge in lawsuit that hospital lost or misplaced body (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sitting in a coffee shop in the Bronx on a recent morning, Eric Stevenson spoke with no shortage of bitterness about the challenge of getting on the ballot in his neophyte run for elective office. Mr. Stevenson, a candidate for an Assembly seat in the Bronx, said that the borough's Democratic organization first challenged the number of valid signatures on his petitions. And when the city's Board of Elections determined that he had indeed exceeded the 500 signatures required, the organization took him to court, saying that his petitions lacked some details on their cover sheets, like the name of the Democratic Party.

headline.main: 22-Year Incumbent Faces Fight After an Unknown Wins a Ballot Spot

docs.abstract: Eric Stevenson wins place on Democratic Party primary ballot in 79th Assembly District in Bronx and is expected to mount serious challenge to Assemblywoman Goria Davis, 22-year incumbent; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I woke around midnight, threw up and went back to sleep. Nausea was nothing new. I had been throwing up constantly -- sometimes as often as 12 times a day -- throughout my pregnancy, but that night something felt different. If I had had to describe my symptoms right then, I would have resorted to the familiar vocabulary of illness -- I was dizzy, my heart was racing, I felt short of breath. I guess. The truth is, those words felt generic and crude, unequal to the task. What I felt was more elemental, as if my bodily organs -- mysterious, essential things I knew I had but couldn't feel -- had begun to malfunction in some subtle, unspeakable way. For the next few hours I lay on the bathroom floor throwing up, letting the tile cool my body as it shook uncontrollably after each episode, first freezing, then burning. A few hours later I got up, went into the bedroom and lay down next to my husband. I could tell from movement on the other side of the bed that he was awake. ''I'm scared,'' I said out loud.
docs.abstract: Rebecca Johnson article describes her pregnancy and diagnosis of pre-eclampsia; says it affects 7 percent of all pregnant women--usually in mild forms--and is one of leading causes of death among pregnant women worldwide; says there is little consensus about what causes it, how it works and, more important, how to treat it; tells sad outcome in her case: her child, Luke, died shortly after being born; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Courtney Lynne Carrera, the daughter of June Carrera and Dr. Michael A. Carrera of Manhattan, was married on Friday to James Bernard, the son of Susan Bernard of Manhattan and Ronald Bernard of Honolulu. Robert Belcher, a Universal Life minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Kahala Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Honolulu. The bride, 33, will continue to use her name professionally. She works for the Children's Aid Society as the program manager for the adolescent pregnancy prevention program in Manhattan and the Bronx. Her father is the national director of pregnancy prevention programs at the Children's Aid Society.
docs.snippet: Courtney Lynne Carrera, the daughter of June Carrera and Dr. Michael A. Carrera of Manhattan, was married on Friday to James Bernard, the son of Susan Bernard of Manhattan and Ronald Bernard of Honolulu. Robert Belcher, a Universal Life minister,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking leads in the gruesome killing of a newborn baby in May, the county attorney here has subpoenaed the names of hundreds of women who had pregnancy tests at a local Planned Parenthood clinic. The organization is fighting the subpoena in the Iowa Supreme Court. Philip E. Havens, the county attorney of Buena Vista County, said the questions had to be asked. ''I don't know how else you deal with it and conduct an investigation,'' he said.

headline.main: Privacy Furor As Baby Death Goes Unsolved

docs.abstract: Prosecutors seeking leads in gruesome killing of newborn baby in Storm Lake, Iowa, subpoena names of hundreds of women who had pregnancy tests at local Planned Parethood clinic and who might have been due to given birth shortly before baby's death late May, but organization is fighting subpoenas in court; organization argues that young women must have confidential source of help to turn in difficult situations; other clinics and local hospital provided informations; Planned Parenthood has support of American Civil Liberties Union and American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-6 Sept. 11 Ringleader Linked to Qaeda Camps Germany has gathered evidence that Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the Sept. 11 attacks, and two accomplices trained at Qaeda camps in Afghanistan from late 1999 to early 2000. Investigators have also established a clear link between Al Qaeda and a recent attack on a Tunisian synagogue. A1 Deadly Russian Politics Russian assassins have trained guns, bombs and even vials of acid on a bewildering array of political officeholders. The deaths are a testament to both the frailty of Russia's emerging justice system and the depth of official corruption. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Do you want to know about the sex life of Sandra, a 33-year-old brunette in Tampa? Just read the Florida newspapers. Sandra is being forced by Florida state law to buy advertisements that give her full name (which I'm not repeating) and physical description: 5 feet 2 inches, 142 pounds, brown eyes. Then, as the law requires, she has to list and describe the five men she had sex with late last summer: Bill, Tommy, Allen, Eric and Joshua.
docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column deplores Florida law that requires woman -- even a 14- or 15-year-old girl or rape victim -- to disclose name and address of father of a baby offered for adoption or to buy newspaper ads in which she gives her name and description and names and descriptions of men whom she cannot locate but with whom she had sex around time of conception; says law, intended to reduce risk of father's emerging years after adoption and seeking custody, is appalling on its own and is part of dismaying neo-puritan drive to ban abortion, replace teaching of contraception with preaching about abstinance and destroy programs that save women's lives in developing countries (M)
